elements.content: Hydrothermal synthesis has afforded a family of five divalent metal succinate (suc) coordination polymers incorporating the kinked dipodal organodiimine 4,4‘-dipyridylamine (dpa), which were structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis. [Co(suc)(dpa)2] (1) manifests chiral helical one-dimensional (1-D) chains formed from the linkage of neighboring Co atoms through bischelating bisbridging succinate moieties, with pendant dpa ligands. {[Ni(dpa)2(suc)0.5]Cl} (2) possesses a rare self-interpenetrated 5-connected cationic framework with a unique 610 topology, constructed from the junction of quadruply interpenetrated adamantoid [Ni(dpa)2]2 n + networks via bischelating μ2-succinate ligands. {[Cu(suc)(dpa)]·0.5H2O} (3) exhibits a doubly interpenetrated CdSO4 net (658 topology) containing both 1-D double braided cationic helical [Cu(dpa)]2+ ribbons and orthogonally situated zigzag [Cu(suc)] chains. The quadruply interpenetrated three-dimensional (3-D) network structure (42638 topology, SrAl2-type) of {[Zn(suc)0.5/2(dpa)]·H2O} (4) is built from [Zn(suc)0.5/2] chains interlocked with dpa tethers. {[Cd(suc)(dpa)]·H2O} (5) displays doubly interpenetrated 6-connected α-Po networks based on {Cd2O2} dimers within [Cd(suc)] two-dimensional (2-D) layers, in turn pillared by dpa ligands. The coordination geometry about the metal atoms and the succinate binding modes and conformations in these compounds vary widely, playing a significant role in promoting the diversity of the observed structural motifs. Supramolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions through the dpa amine subunit are evident in all cases.

elements.content: Hydrothermal synthesis has afforded five divalent metal succinate coordination polymers incorporating 4,4‘-dipyridylamine, where coordination geometry preferences play a large role in structure direction. Helical chain motifs and doubly and quadruply interpenetrated networks are observed. The nickel derivative displays the first 5-connected framework with a uniform 610 topology and is also a rare example of a self-interpenetrated coordination polymer net.

elements.content: Interest remains high in the synthesis and characterization of metal−organic framework (MOF) materials because of their potential utility in hydrogen storage, shape-selective separations, ion exchange, catalysis, nonlinear optics, and luminescence. In many of these phases, dianionic dicarboxylate ligands have been employed to conjoin cationic metal nodes, in the process providing the necessary charge balance to permit construction of a wide variety of neutral MOFs without incorporation of counterions that could inhibit porosity. An extremely diverse range of structural motifs occurs in these systems, predicated on the disposition of the donor atoms within the organic moiety and the coordination geometry preferences of the metal cations. The structural diversity and property applications of dicarboxylate MOFs have been recently expanded by the incorporation of neutral tethering organodiimines such as 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bpy). For example, the 2-D phase {[Zn(isophthalate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)]·1.5 H2O}7a and the double layered solid {[Zn(isophthalate)(4,4‘-bpy)2(H2O)][Zn(isophthalate)(4,4‘-bpy)]·0.25H2O}7b have potential use as blue luminescent materials, and the interpenetrated 3-D material [Zn(terephthalate)(4,4‘-bpy)0.5] can chromatographically separate branched and linear hydrocarbons.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Interest remains high in the synthesis and characterization of metal-organic framework (MOF) materials because of their potential utility in hydrogen storage, shape-selective separations, ion exchange, catalysis, nonlinear optics, and luminescence. In many of these phases, dianionic dicarboxylate ligands have been employed to conjoin cationic metal nodes, in the process providing the necessary charge balance to permit construction of a wide variety of neutral MOFs without incorporation of counterions that could inhibit porosity. An extremely diverse range of structural motifs occurs in these systems, predicated on the disposition of the donor atoms within the organic moiety and the coordination geometry preferences of the metal cations. The structural diversity and property applications of dicarboxylate MOFs have been recently expanded by the incorporation of neutral tethering organodiimines such as 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bpy). For example, the 2-D phase {[Zn(isophthalate)(4,4‘-bpy)(H2O)]⋅1.5 H2O}7a and the double layered solid {[Zn(isophthalate)(4,4‘-bpy)2(H2O)][Zn(isophthalate)(4,4‘-bpy)]⋅0.25H2O}7b have potential use as blue luminescent materials, and the interpenetrated 3-D material [Zn(terephthalate)(4,4‘-bpy)0.5] can chromatographically separate branched and linear hydrocarbons.

elements.content: Compared with benzenedicarboxylate MOFs, organodiimine-scaffolded coordination polymers based on longer aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylates have received less attention. While the structural rigidity of benzenedicarboxylate subunits can be advantageous for the construction of porous materials, flexible aliphatic dicarboxylates can result in novel coordination polymer structural motifs due to their ability to access numerous energetically similar conformations. For instance, the succinate dianion (suc, 1,4-butanedioate) has been shown to adopt anti, gauche, and intermediate conformations when incorporated into coordination polymer systems, thus provoking one-dimensional (1-D) chain, two-dimensional (2-D) layer, and three-dimensional (3-D) diamondoid or α-Po frameworks.

For instance, the succinate dianion (suc, 1,4-butanedioate) has been shown to adopt anti, gauche, and intermediate conformations when incorporated into coordination polymer systems, thus provoking one-dimensional (1-D) chain, two-dimensional (2-D) layer, and three-dimensional (3-D) diamondoid or α-Po frameworks.

elements.content: For some time, we have been interested in the synthesis and characterization of coordination polymers containing the organodiimine 4,4‘-dipyridylamine (dpa). In contrast to 4,4‘-bpy, dpa possesses a kinked disposition of its distal nitrogen donor atoms as well as a potential hydrogen-bonding point of contact, allowing it to aggregate MOF subunits via supramolecular as well as covalent interactions in oxide or carboxylate systems. In our hands, hydrothermal treatment of transition metal precursors with dpa has resulted in the construction of extended solids with diverse structural motifs. For example, {[Cu2(phthalate)2(dpa)]·H2O} forms 1-D chiral helical nanotubules with hydrophobic cores, {[CuMoO4(dpa)2]·2H2O} possesses unique 2-D copper molybdate layers strutted by dpa tethers, and [NiMoO4(dpa)2] has a “starburst” 3-D structure formed by molybdate-linked cationic [Ni(dpa)2]2 n + layers. This work has been extended into monovalent silver and divalent cadmium oxoanion and pseudohalide systems by Hanton and colleagues. We report here the hydrothermal synthesis, structural characterization, and spectral and thermal degradation analysis of five new divalent metal dpa-bearing succinate coordination polymers, wherein metal coordination geometry, carboxylate binding mode, succinate conformation, and dpa-based hydrogen-bonding patterns all play a synergistic role in structure direction.

General Considerations. Hydrated metal chlorides and metal nitrates and succinic acid were obtained from Fisher. 4,4‘-Dipyridylamine (dpa) was prepared via a published procedure. Water was deionized above 3 MΩ in-house. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments TGA 2050 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 900 °C. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Mattson Galaxy FTIR Series 3000 using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction on ground samples of 1−5 for phase purity verification was obtained via ϑ -2ϑ scans performed on a Rigaku Rotaflex instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Considerations. Hydrated metal chlorides and metal nitrates and succinic acid were obtained from Fisher. 4,4‘-Dipyridylamine (dpa) was prepared via a published procedure. Water was deionized above 3 MΩ in-house. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments TGA 2050 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 900 °C. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Mattson Galaxy FTIR Series 3000 using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction on ground samples of 1-5 for phase purity verification was obtained via ϑ -2ϑ scans performed on a Rigaku Rotaflex instrument.

elements.content: Preparation of [Co(suc)(dpa) 2 ] (1). CoCl2·6H2O (89.0 mg, 0.37 mmol), dpa (127 mg, 0.74 mmol), and succinic acid (44 mg, 0.37 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O (mole ratio 1:2:1:1500) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. NaOH (1.0 M, 0.5 mL, 0.5 mmol) was added to basicify the solution. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Magenta blocks of 1 (55 mg, 29% yield based on Co) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Anal. Calc. for C24H22CoN6O4 1:  C, 55.71; H, 4.29; N, 16.24%; Found:  C, 55.49; H, 4.08; N, 16.00%. elements.content: Preparation of {[Cd(suc)(dpa)] · H 2 O} (5). Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (110 mg, 0.33 mmol), dpa (127 mg, 0.74 mmol), and succinic acid (43 mg, 0.33 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. NaOH (1.0 M, 1.0 mL, 1.0 mmol) was added to basicify the solution. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Straw-colored blocks of 5 (31 mg, 14% yield based on Cd) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Anal. Calc. for C14H15CdN3O5 5:  C, 40.26; H, 3.62; N, 10.06%; Found:  C, 38.40; H, 3.76; N, 9.33%. Analyses on several samples showed lower than expected values for C and N, either due to incomplete combustion or amorphous impurities. The crystal structure and thermogravimetric analysis are both consistent with the presence of one water molecule of crystallization per Cd atom. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3436 s br, 3062 w, 2970 w, 1599 s, 1529 s, 1444 m, 1417 m, 1385 m, 1219 m, 1016 m, 933 w, 902 w, 871 w, 816 m, 673 w, 594 w, 532 w.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. A magenta block of 1 (with dimensions 0.30 × 0.28 × 0.08 mm), a blue block of 2 (0.42 × 0.26 × 0.26 mm), a blue parallepiped of 3 (0.30 × 0.20 × 0.20 mm), a colorless rhomb of 4 (0.35 × 0.30 × 0.30 mm), and a straw-colored block of 5 (0.16 × 0.15 × 0.14 mm) were subjected to single-crystal X-ray diffraction using a Bruker-AXS SMART 1k CCD instrument. Reflection data was acquired using graphite−monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data was integrated via SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms bound to the central nitrogen of the dpa moieties, and any water molecules (except for those in 4) were found via Fourier difference maps, then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. Disordered succinate ligands in 1 and 4, and disordered enclathrated species in 2 and 4, were successfully modeled using partial occupancies. Distended thermal ellipsoids on one ring of the dpa moiety in 4 are indicative of some torsional disorder due to σ bond rotation during crystallization. Although this disorder could not be successfully modeled, the involved atoms are not especially germane to the coordination polymer connectivity. Relevant crystallographic data for 1−5 are listed in Table .

Reflection data was acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data was integrated via SAINT. elements.content: Synthesis and Spectral Characterization. The coordination polymers 1−5 were prepared cleanly as single phase crystalline products under hydrothermal conditions via combination of the appropriate metal chloride, 4,4‘-dipyridylamine, and succinic acid, with pH adjustment in all cases. The infrared spectra of 1−5 were fully consistent with their formulations. Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600 cm-1 to ∼1200 cm-1 were ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the dpa moieties. Features corresponding to pyridyl ring puckering exist in the region between 820 and 600 cm-1. Asymmetric and symmetric C−O stretching modes of the fully deprotonated, ligated succinate moieties were evidenced by very strong, slightly broadened bands at ∼1600 cm-1 and ∼1400 cm-1. The absence of any bands in the area of ∼1710 cm-1 indicates full deprotonation of all carboxylate groups in 1−5. Broad bands in the region of ∼3400 cm-1 to ∼3200 cm-1 in all cases represent N−H stretching modes within the dpa ligands and O−H stretching modes within either aquo ligands water molecules of crystallization, where present. The broadness of these latter spectral features is caused by significant hydrogen-bonding pathways within 1−5.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis and Spectral Characterization. The coordination polymers 1-5 were prepared cleanly as single phase crystalline products under hydrothermal conditions via combination of the appropriate metal chloride, 4,4‘-dipyridylamine, and succinic acid, with pH adjustment in all cases. The infrared spectra of 1-5 were fully consistent with their formulations. Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600 cm-1 to ~1200 cm-1 were ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the dpa moieties. Features corresponding to pyridyl ring puckering exist in the region between 820 and 600 cm-1. Asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching modes of the fully deprotonated, ligated succinate moieties were evidenced by very strong, slightly broadened bands at ~1600 cm-1 and ~1400 cm-1. The absence of any bands in the area of ~1710 cm-1 indicates full deprotonation of all carboxylate groups in 1-5. Broad bands in the region of ~3400 cm-1 to ~3200 cm-1 in all cases represent N-H stretching modes within the dpa ligands and O-H stretching modes within either aquo ligands water molecules of crystallization, where present. The broadness of these latter spectral features is caused by significant hydrogen-bonding pathways within 1-5.

elements.content: Structural Description of [Co(suc)(dpa) 2 ] (1). X-ray diffraction revealed that 1 crystallized in the chiral hexagonal space group P3121, with a Flack parameter of 0.08(2), indicating high enantiomeric excess. Spontaneous resolution of enantiomerically pure coordination polymer crystals from achiral precursors is not uncommon and has been observed previously in dpa coordination polymers due to the ligand's ability to act as a double-bladed propeller that can lock into position in the solid state. While it was not directly probed, it is likely that a sample of crystalline 1 would contain a racemic mixture of crystals with enantiomorphic space groups P3121 and P3221. The asymmetric unit of 1 (Figure ) consists of one-half-occupancy cobalt atom on a 2-fold crystallographic axis, one-half of a succinate ligand with a chelating carboxylate binding mode (disordered equally over two sets of positions), and one dpa moiety with an inter-ring torsion angle of 25.3°. A complete anti-conformation succinate dianion is formed by a C22A−C22B bond between two different disordered subunits. The [CoO4N2] coordination sphere about Co is best described as distorted octahedral, with chelating succinate carboxylate “bite angles” of 59.4° and 61.3°, and trans bond angles ranging between 140.5° and 166°. The chelation of the succinate ligand is asymmetric, with Co−O bond lengths varying by 0.139 and 0.317 Å at each respective carboxylate terminus. The dpa nitrogen donors are oriented in a widened cis fashion (N−Co−N bond angle ∼107°). Selected bond length and angle information for 1 is given in Table .

Extension of the asymmetric unit along the 31 crystallographic screw axis shows the presence of 1-D [Co(suc)(dpa)2] helical chains built from the junction of neighboring Co atoms by anti-conformation (four C-atom torsion angle = ∼178°) bischelating bisbridging succinate anions (Figure ). The Co−Co distance across the succinate bridge is 8.82 Å. The pitch of a single 3-fold helix, marked by the third-nearest neighbor Co−Co separation, is 19.464(2) Å. In 1, the pendant dpa moieties bind to Co only at one terminus, with the distal nitrogen atom of the dpa ligands remaining unligated and unprotonated. The monodenticity of unprotonated dpa has been previously observed only in the polyoxomolybdate cluster complex {[(H2dpa)2][Mo8O26(dpa)2]}. The helical 1-D chain motif based on bisbidentate bisbridging succinate ligands in 1 is reminiscent of that seen in [Zn(suc)(4,4‘-bpy)2], wherein the pendant 4,4‘-bpy ligands also adopt a seldom-seen monodentate binding mode.

elements.content: Neighboring 1-D [Co(suc)(dpa)2] helical chains aggregate to form the pseudo 3-D crystal structure of 1 via supramolecular interactions between the central N−H portions of the dpa ligands and ligated carboxylate oxygen atoms (of type O2 and O2A) belonging to succinate moieties in abutting chains. As can be seen in Figure , in which the structure of 1 is viewed down the c crystal axis, each [Co(suc)(dpa)2] chain donates hydrogen bonds from its dpa N−H subunits to carboxylate oxygen atoms in three other chains and accepts hydrogen bonds at its own carboxylate oxygen atoms from three other neighboring chains. Thus, each individual helix is supramolecularly conjoined to six others, arranged in a hexagonal pattern around the “central” helix. The closest Co−Co through-space separation between adjacent [Co(suc)(dpa)2] helices is ∼8.61 Å, slightly closer than the corresponding through-ligand distance within a single helix. Metrical parameters for the supramolecular interactions in 1 (and 2−5, vide infra) are given in Table .

Several chiral divalent zinc and cadmium coordination polymers have manifested nonlinear optical second harmonic generation (SHG) behavior. Unfortunately, the colored nature of crystals of 1 precluded study of possible visible-light SHG behavior. The possibility of the synthesis of chiral coordination polymers in this system nevertheless motivated exploratory efforts toward zinc and cadmium succinate/dpa materials, reported below.

elements.content: Structural Description of {[Ni(dpa) 2 (suc) 0.5 ]Cl} (2). The asymmetric unit of 2 (Figure ) consists of one nickel atom, one-half of a succinate dianion, two crystallographically distinct dpa units (dpa-1, marked by N1−N3 with an inter-ring torsion angle of 34.4° and dpa-2, denoted by N4−N6 with a related torsion angle of 36.7°), and an unligated chloride ion disordered over two positions (successfully modeled with partial occupancies at 93 and 7%). The octahedral [NiN4O2] coordination environment is less distorted than the [CoO4N2] coordination sphere in 1, due to the presence of only one chelating succinate moiety. The trans bond angles across the [NiN4O2] octahedra range from 158.5° to 173.5°. Here, the carboxylate oxygen atoms bind much more symmetrically than in 1, with Ni−O bond distances of 2.098 and 2.133 Å. The chelating carboxylate bite angle in 2 is 62.6°. The nitrogen donors from two different dpa-1 ligands bind to Ni in a cis manner, as do the nitrogen donors from two disparate dpa-2 moieties.

elements.content: Ni atoms in 2 are linked into binuclear [Ni2(suc)]2+ kernels (Figure ) by bischelating, bisbridging gauche conformation succinate anions (four C-atom torsion angle = ∼117°) with a through-ligand metal-metal contact distance of 7.63 Å, about 1.2 Å shorter than in 1. These “linear” binuclear kernels are oriented parallel to the c crystal axis and are similar to the previously reported [(phen)Zn(μ-suc)Zn(phen)]2+ complex cation, although the latter manifests strictly anti conformation bisbidentate bisbridging succinate tethers. The contraction of the through-dicarboxylate metal−metal distance in 2 relative to 1 is attributable to the more folded gauche conformation of the succinate bridge. Relevant bond distance and angle information for 2 is given in Table .

elements.content: Extending the structure of 2 through both distinct types of dpa ligand forms a quadruply interpenetrated 4-connected cationic [Ni(dpa)2]2 n + 3-D adamantoid framework structure, similar to that seen in {[Ni(dpa)2(SO4)(H2O)]·2H2O}15 and its cadmium sulfate and nitrate congeners. As in these cases, the cis disposition of the non-imine ligands in 2 promotes a pseudo-tetrahedral arrangement of the distal nitrogen donors on the periphery of a single nickel coordination octahedron, resulting in the observed adamantoid substructure. The chelating binding mode of the succinate carboxylate units enforces a cis disposition of the oxygen donors at each nickel, thus preventing the formation of infinite 2-D [Ni(dpa)2]2 n + layers as seen in [NiMoO4(dpa)2] in which the molybdate anions are trans-disposed at each Ni atom.

Adjacent individual [Ni(dpa)2]2 n + 3-D adamantoid nets are covalently linked through the bischelating bisbridging succinate ions to construct a [Ni(dpa)2(suc)0.5] n + 5-connected 3-D cationic network with a uniform 610 topology (long vertex symbol 63.63. 63.63.63.63.63.63.63.63), the first of its type to the best of our knowledge. Moreover, 2 is a rare example of a self-interpenetrated network, where rods of the same framework penetrate through the shortest internodal circuits. Figure depicts a perspective of this covalently connected cationic network, with each independent [Ni(dpa)2]2 n + adamantoid net drawn in a different color and the pillaring self-interpenetrating succinate ligands shown in pink. Incipient void spaces (9.4% of the unit cell volume according to PLATON) coursing through the self-interpenetrated framework are occupied by chloride counteranions, anchored in place by hydrogen-bonding acceptance from the N−H central subunits of both types of tethering dpa ligands (contact distance and angle information is given in Table ).

elements.content: Structural Description of {[Cu(suc)(dpa)] · 0.5H 2 O} (3). The asymmetric unit of 3 (Figure ) consists of one divalent copper atom, one doubly deprotonated succinate ligand, one twisted dpa moiety (inter-ring torsion angle = 43.9°), and a half-occupancy water molecule of crystallization situated on the crystallographic 2-fold rotation axis along c. The Cu atom in 3 presents a square planar [CuO2N2] coordination geometry, where the nitrogen donors from two different dpa ligands are oriented in a trans fashion about Cu, as are carboxylate oxygen donors (O1 and O3) from different termini of two different succinate ligands. Bond lengths and angles (Table ) about Cu are standard for square planar coordination.

In contrast to 1 and 2, the succinate ligands in 3 adopt a bismonodentate bisbridging binding mode, although weak “4 + 2” type interactions, common for Jahn−Teller active d9 metal ions, can be invoked between the unligated carboxylate oxygen atoms and Cu (Cu···O2 and Cu···O4 distances are 2.62 and 2.68 Å, respectively). The succinate ligands rest in a slightly distorted anti conformation (four C-atom torsion angle = 163.4°). Two Cu atoms bind to each succinate anion at carboxylate oxygen atoms on the same side of the aliphatic tether, so that neutral zigzag 1-D [Cu(suc)] chains with a Cu−Cu distance of 8.504(1) Å are formed (Figure ). Mutually orthogonal sets of these chains run parallel to the a and b crystal directions. These chain motifs are extremely similar to those in the very recently reported 1-D material {[Cu(suc)(H2O)2]· 2H2O}, which also exhibits bismonodentate bisbridging succinate dianions. Dissimilar to 1, the succinate ions in the imine-free hydrated congener adopt a strictly anti conformation (180° torsion angle). It is likely that hydrogen bonding by the dpa N−H subunit to unligated succinate carboxylate oxygen atoms (vide infra) subtly contorts the conformation of the aliphatic tether in 3.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to 1 and 2, the succinate ligands in 3 adopt a bismonodentate bisbridging binding mode, although weak "4 + 2" type interactions, common for Jahn-Teller active d9 metal ions, can be invoked between the unligated carboxylate oxygen atoms and Cu (Cu⋅⋅⋅O2 and Cu⋅⋅⋅O4 distances are 2.62 and 2.68 Å, respectively). The succinate ligands rest in a slightly distorted anti conformation (four C-atom torsion angle = 163.4°). Two Cu atoms bind to each succinate anion at carboxylate oxygen atoms on the same side of the aliphatic tether, so that neutral zigzag 1-D [Cu(suc)] chains with a Cu-Cu distance of 8.504(1) Å are formed (Figure ). Mutually orthogonal sets of these chains run parallel to the a and b crystal directions. These chain motifs are extremely similar to those in the very recently reported 1-D material {[Cu(suc)(H2O)2]⋅ 2H2O}, which also exhibits bismonodentate bisbridging succinate dianions. Dissimilar to 1, the succinate ions in the imine-free hydrated congener adopt a strictly anti conformation (180° torsion angle). It is likely that hydrogen bonding by the dpa N-H subunit to unligated succinate carboxylate oxygen atoms (vide infra) subtly contorts the conformation of the aliphatic tether in 3.

elements.content: The [Cu(suc)] 1-D chains in 3 are in turn strutted by tethering dpa ligands, resulting in a doubly interpenetrated 658 topology 4-connected 3-D framework (Figure ), where each distinct network mirrors the square planar node 4-connected structure of CdSO4 reflecting the structural information imparted by square planar coordination at copper. The dpa-bridged Cu−Cu distance between two orthogonally disposed [Cu(suc)] chains is 11.231(2) Å. The structure of 3 alternatively may be considered to contain cationic [Cu(dpa)]2 4 n + 4-fold double helices (Figure ), which course along the c crystal axis. The helices are threaded along the crystallographic 41 screw axes with a repeat distance of ∼40.75 Å as defined by the fourth-nearest neighbor Cu−Cu distance (in the process marking the c lattice parameter). Each [Cu(dpa)]2 4 n + double helix is then connected to four proximal double helices, two along the ac plane and two along bc plane, via tethering bismonodentate succinate anions. This covalent attachment of the structural subunits to form the overall 3-D coordination polymer network of 3 is augmented by supramolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions between the central secondary amine portions of the dpa ligands and unligated carboxylate oxygen atoms of type O2. Water molecules of crystallization reside within the 3-D network, anchored via hydrogen bonding to unligated carboxylate oxygen atoms of type O4. Details for all supramolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions in 3 are given in Table .

elements.content: Structural Description of {[Zn(suc) 0.5/2 (dpa)] · H 2 O} (4). The asymmetric unit of 4 (Figure ) contains one zinc atom, two halves of two crystallographically distinct deprotonated succinate ligands (suc-a, denoted by C21, C22, O1, O2; suc-b, marked by C31, C32, O3, O4), and one virtually flat dpa ligand (inter-ring torsion angle of ∼1.4°), along with disordered water molecules of crystallization at two positions, successfully modeled using partial occupancies. The sum of the water molecule occupancies is one per asymmetric unit. In addition, the succinate ligand of type suc-b is disordered over two sets of positions in a 70:30 ratio. In contrast to 1−3, the coordination environment about Zn in 4 is distorted tetrahedral, with a [ZnO2N2] arrangement and bond angles ranging between 97.4° and 119.3°. The Zn−O bond distances are slightly shorter than the Zn−N distances. Pertinent bond lengths and angles for 4 are listed in Table .

a  Atoms marked with the designation A refer to the minor component of the disordered suc-b ligand. Symmetry transformations to generate equivalent atoms:  (#1) x − 1/2, −y + 1/2, z − 1/2.

As in 3, neighboring metal atoms are linked covalently into a 1-D chain through bismonodentate, bisbridging succinate anions. However, unlike in 3, the oxygen donor atoms now lie on opposite sides of the aliphatic tether. Two crystallographically distinct succinate ligands are present in 4, with suc-a resting in a perfectly anti conformation (torsion angle = 180°) and suc-b adopting a gauche conformation (torsion angle = 84.9°). These conformational differences cause the Zn−Zn separations along the resulting [Zn(suc)0.5/2] neutral 1-D chains to toggle between values of 8.795(1) and 8.303(1) Å (Figure ). The neutral [Zn(suc)0.5/2] subunits aggregate covalently through tethering dpa ligands, with a Zn−Zn interchain distance of 11.397(2) Å, to form quadruply interpenetrated [Zn(suc)0.5/2(dpa)] 3-D 4-connected networks with an uncommon 42638 topology (SrAl2 structure type)30a as seen in Figure . Four-fold interpenetration within coordination polymers with the SrAl2 structural morphology was observed previously in [Ag(sebaconitrile)2]EF6 (E = As, Sb). While the majority of interpenetrated 4-connected coordination polymer networks with tetrahedral connecting nodes adopt a diamondoid morphology, the optimization of covalent and supramolecular internetwork interaction pathways can promote the formation of other structure types. The SrAl2 framework of 4 is further evidence of the energetic accessibility of non-diamondoid connectivity patterns during coordination polymer self-assembly. A level of connectivity between the four independent networks in 4 is provided by supramolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions between N−H subunits in the dpa ligands and unligated carboxylate oxygen atoms of type O4. Disordered water molecules of crystallization fit into small incipient voids (6.6% of unit cell volume), held in place via hydrogen bonding to unligated carboxylate oxygen atoms of type O2. Details for the noncovalent attractive interactions in 4 are stated in Table .

elements.content: Structural Description of {[Cd(suc)(dpa)] · H 2 O} (5). The asymmetric unit of 5 (Figure ) possesses one cadmium atom and one doubly deprotonated, completely anti-conformation succinate ligand lying on a crystallographic mirror plane, and one-half of a dpa molecule, along with a water molecule of crystallization. The Cd atoms in 5 display [CdO5N2] pentagonal bipyramidal coordination, with succinate oxygen donors situated in the equatorial plane and dpa nitrogen donors oriented in a trans fashion in the axial positions. This coordination geometry is similar to the [CdO7] pentagonal bipyramidal arrangement seen in the related imine-free hydrated cadmium succinate phase [Cd(suc)(H2O)2]. In 5, the axially disposed Cd−N bond lengths are shorter than all Cd−O bond lengths; the N−Cd−N angle subtends ∼161°. Because of the presence of two chelating succinate carboxylates with bite angles of 53.8° and 54.4°, significantly less than an idealized 72° equatorial bond angle, the coordination environment at Cd is best described as distorted pentagonal bipyramidal. Bond lengths and angles for 5 are given in Table .

Likely provoked by the larger ionic radius of divalent Cd, each succinate dianion in 5 bridges three Cd atoms, two through a bisbidentate bisbridging mode, with an additional Cd atom bound to one of the carboxylate oxygen atoms. This μ3-succinate binding mode, taken together with the strictly anti conformation of the aliphatic tether and the pentagonal bipyramidal coordination sphere at Cd, causes propagation of infinite 2-D [Cd(suc)] neutral layers (Figure ). These are completely coplanar with the bc crystal planes if hydrogen atoms are neglected. The [Cd(suc)] layers may also be construed as coplanar aggregations of atom-sharing Cd2O2 and CdOCO four-membered rings and 28-membered (CdOC4O)4 elliptical circuits. The through-space distances across the Cd2O2 rhomboids measure 3.844(1) Å (Cd−Cd) × 3.096(1) Å (O−O). The Cd−Cd distance through the bisbidentate bisbridging segment of the anti conformation μ3-succinate ligands is ∼9.27 Å, while the through-space Cd−Cd distances across the larger 28-membered ring subunits are ∼11.62 and ∼14.50 Å.

elements.content: Individual [Cd(suc)] layers are then pillared into a 3-D network (Figure ) by means of virtually flat (0° inter-ring torsion) dpa ligands oriented parallel to the a crystal axis. Because of steric interactions between the 2- and 2‘-position C−H units of the dpa moieties, the inter-ring C3−N3−C8 bond angle widens to ∼134°, thereby lengthening the dpa tether to allow a Cd−Cd interlayer distance of 12.500(2) Å. Because of the close Cd−Cd contact distance between the Cd2O2 bimetallic kernels in each [Cd(suc)] layer, the dpa ligands conjoining two of these respective units can also interact via π−π stacking (3.675(2) Å). Open void space within the 3-D network is minimized by the interpenetration of a second identical 3-D network, where the [Cd(suc)] flat layers in one network weave around the centers of the dpa tethers in the second network. Supramolecular hydrogen bonding between the dpa amine subunits and chelating succinate carboxylate oxygens of type O2 promotes the favorability of this interaction.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analysis of 1 − 5 . The decomposition behavior of 1−5 was examined via thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The mass of 1 remains largely unchanged until the decomposition onset temperature of ∼290 °C. A 54.4% weight loss occurred by 360 °C, consistent with the loss of 1 equiv of dpa and 1 equiv of suc (55.4% predicted). All removal of organics was complete by 535 °C, indicated by a further weight loss of 32.1%, roughly consistent with expulsion of the second equivalent of dpa. The final mass remnant of 13.5% was consistent with deposition of CoO (14.4% predicted). The thermal stability of 2 was slightly greater, with an onset temperature for degradation of ∼310 °C. A precipitous weight loss of 55.7% was complete by 390 °C, corresponding to fracture of the self-interpenetrated framework with the expulsion of all suc moieties, 1 equiv of dpa, and 1 equiv of HCl (53.7% calculated). A further mass loss of 30.9% occurred between 390 and 555 °C, marking the elimination of the second equivalent of dpa. The final mass remnant of 15.4% was very close to that predicted for NiO (15.1%). 3 slowly dehydrates on heating from 25 to 225 °C (observed weight loss 2.4%, 2.5% calculated for one-half equivalent of water), followed immediately by rapid elimination of all organic moieties. The remnant at 425 °C (26.0%) is indicative of a mixture of CuCO3 and CuO. A subsequent slow decrease in mass to 800 °C likely marks further decarboxylation. The TGA trace of 4 revealed dehydration in two steps completed by 125 °C (7.0% observed, 5.0% calculated), followed by a plateau to ∼275 °C, whereupon combustion of all organic ligands commenced. The 21.9% mass remnant at 800 °C is consistent with ZnO (21.8% predicted). Compound 5 exhibited a slow mass loss of 4.5% between ∼200 °C and ∼270 °C, consistent with explusion of the cocrystallized water (4.3% predicted). Complete combustion of all organic components commenced soon thereafter, with a remnant at 450 °C roughly consistent with deposition of Cd metal (26.9% predicted, 24.0% observed). A slow mass loss above this temperature, followed by a rapid mass loss above ∼760 °C, is attributed to volatilization and vaporization of the Cd metal (bp 765 °C). TGA traces for 1−5 are given in Figures S1−S5 (Supporting Information).

elements.content: Hydrothermal combination of divalent transition metal precursors with succinic acid and 4,4‘-dipyridylamine has afforded the preparation of a family of five new coordination polymers, taking advantage of enhanced structural diversity imparted by the kinked nitrogen donor disposition and hydrogen-bonding capability of the dpa tethering ligand. While 1 exhibits chiral 1-D helical chain subunits constructed from the connection of octahedrally coordinated Co atoms through bischelating exobidentate succinate bridges, 2−5 all manifest interpenetrated 3-D structures fomented by the linkage of metal atoms through both difunctional dpa and succinate ligands. Nevertheless, 2−5 display different degrees of interpenetration and network topologies, predicated largely on variances in the respective metal coordination preferences. The nickel derivative 2 manifests a unique self-interpenetrated 5-connected 610 topology network. In each material, the covalent and supramolecular interactions imposed by the carboxylate conformation (anti, gauche, or both forms) and binding mode (bischelating, bismonodentate, or triply bridging) serve an important role in accessing the observed coordination polymer structural morphology during self-assembly. Hydrogen-bonding pathways made possible by the amine functional group of the dpa ligand are also significant structure directing factors. 1−5 displayed a modicum of thermal robustness, consistent with 3-D covalent (2−5) or strongly hydrogen bonded (1) networks. Further efforts are underway in our laboratory to explore the construction of aliphatic and aromatic dicarboxylate-based coordination polymers by employing the unique covalent and supramolecular structure-directing properties of 4,4‘-dipyridylamine.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Hydrothermal combination of divalent transition metal precursors with succinic acid and 4,4‘-dipyridylamine has afforded the preparation of a family of five new coordination polymers, taking advantage of enhanced structural diversity imparted by the kinked nitrogen donor disposition and hydrogen-bonding capability of the dpa tethering ligand. While 1 exhibits chiral 1-D helical chain subunits constructed from the connection of octahedrally coordinated Co atoms through bischelating exobidentate succinate bridges, 2-5 all manifest interpenetrated 3-D structures fomented by the linkage of metal atoms through both difunctional dpa and succinate ligands. Nevertheless, 2-5 display different degrees of interpenetration and network topologies, predicated largely on variances in the respective metal coordination preferences. The nickel derivative 2 manifests  a unique self-interpenetrated 5-connected 610 topology network. In each material, the covalent and supramolecular interactions imposed by the carboxylate conformation (anti, gauche, or both forms) and binding mode (bischelating, bismonodentate, or triply bridging) serve an important role in accessing the observed coordination polymer structural morphology during self-assembly. Hydrogen-bonding pathways made possible by the amine functional group of the dpa ligand are also significant structure directing factors. 1-5 displayed a modicum of thermal robustness, consistent with 3-D covalent (2-5) or strongly hydrogen bonded (1) networks. Further efforts are underway in our laboratory to explore the construction of aliphatic and aromatic dicarboxylate-based coordination polymers by employing the unique covalent and supramolecular structure-directing properties of 4,4‘-dipyridylamine.

Preparation of [Co(suc)(dpa) 2 ] (1). CoCl2·6H2O (89.0 mg, 0.37 mmol), dpa (127 mg, 0.74 mmol), and succinic acid (44 mg, 0.37 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O (mole ratio 1:2:1:1500) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. NaOH (1.0 M, 0.5 mL, 0.5 mmol) was added to basicify the solution. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Magenta blocks of 1 (55 mg, 29% yield based on Co) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Anal. Calc. for C24H22CoN6O4 1:  C, 55.71; H, 4.29; N, 16.24%; Found:  C, 55.49; H, 4.08; N, 16.00%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3285 m, 3174 m, 3085 m, 3062 m, 2994 m, 2926 m, 2366 w, 2339 w, 1979 w, 1944 w, 1619 s, 1592 s, 1519 s, 1489 m, 1438 m, 1412 s, 1358 s, 1325 m, 1224 m, 1213 m, 1065 w, 1051 w, 1021 m, 990 w, 811 s, 762 w, 734 w, 729 w, 696 m, 661 w, 638 w, 589 m, 539 m.

Preparation of {[Ni(dpa) 2 (suc) 0.5 ]Cl} (2). NiCl2·6H2O (88 mg, 0.37 mmol), dpa (127 mg, 0.74 mmol), and succinic acid (22 mg, 0.18 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. NaOH (1.0 M, 0.5 mL, 0.5 mmol) was added to basicify the solution. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Blue prisms of 2 (40 mg, 22% yield based on Ni) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Anal. Calc. for C22H20ClN6NiO2 2:  C, 53.43; H, 4.08; N, 16.99%; Found:  C, 52.88; H, 3.90; N, 16.47%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3450 vb, s, 3247 s, 3052 s, 2363 m, 1699 m, 1600 s, 1560 m, 1515 s, 1489 m, 1439 m, 1351 m, 1339 m, 1209 m, 1071 w, 1056 w, 1029 m, 1014 w, 906 w, 861 w, 818 m, 781 w, 730 w, 673 w, 660 w, 641 w, 589 w, 535 w.

Preparation of {[Cu(suc)(dpa)] · 0.5H 2 O} (3). CuCl2·2H2O (63 mg, 0.37 mmol), dpa (127 mg, 0.74 mmol), and succinic acid (43 mg, 0.37 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. NaOH (1.0 M, 1.0 mL, 1.0 mmol) was added to basicify the solution. The bomb was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 48 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Dark blue blocks of 3 (90 mg, 69% yield based on Cu) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Anal. Calc. for C14H14CuN3O4.5 3:  C, 46.73; H, 3.92; N, 11.68%; Found:  C, 46.67; H, 4.08; N, 11.80%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3248 w br, 2975 w, 2895 w, 1592 s, 1559 m, 1542 m, 1513 s, 1437 m, 1403 m, 1357 m, 1336 s, 1311 m, 1266 w, 1204 s, 1153 w, 1100 w, 1057 m, 1025 m, 961 w, 925 w, 905 w, 866 w, 821 s, 730 w, 662 s.

Preparation of {[Zn(suc) 0.5/2 (dpa)] · H 2 O} (4). ZnCl2 (75 mg, 0.55 mmol), dpa (94 mg, 0.55 mmol), and succinic acid (65 mg, 0.55 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. NaOH (1.0 M, 0.5 mL, 0.5 mmol) was added to basicify the solution. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Colorless rhombs of 4 (110 mg, 54% yield based on Zn) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Anal. Calc. for C14H15N3O5Zn 4:  C, 45.36; H, 4.08; N, 11.34%; Found:  C, 45.19; H, 3.84; N, 11.57%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3465 m br, 3296 m, 2977 w, 2923 w, 1600 s, 1523 s, 1492 m, 1454 m, 1388 m, 1355 m, 1288 w, 1234 w, 1209 m, 1060 m, 1028 m, 916 w, 864 w, 820 m, 690 w, 661 w, 605 w, 536 m.

Preparation of {[Cd(suc)(dpa)] · H 2 O} (5). Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (110 mg, 0.33 mmol), dpa (127 mg, 0.74 mmol), and succinic acid (43 mg, 0.33 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. NaOH (1.0 M, 1.0 mL, 1.0 mmol) was added to basicify the solution. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Straw-colored blocks of 5 (31 mg, 14% yield based on Cd) were isolated after washing with distilled water, ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Anal. Calc. for C14H15CdN3O5 5:  C, 40.26; H, 3.62; N, 10.06%; Found:  C, 38.40; H, 3.76; N, 9.33%. Analyses on several samples showed lower than expected values for C and N, either due to incomplete combustion or amorphous impurities. The crystal structure and thermogravimetric analysis are both consistent with the presence of one water molecule of crystallization per Cd atom. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3436 s br, 3062 w, 2970 w, 1599 s, 1529 s, 1444 m, 1417 m, 1385 m, 1219 m, 1016 m, 933 w, 902 w, 871 w, 816 m, 673 w, 594 w, 532 w.

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analysis of 1 − 5 . The decomposition behavior of 1−5 was examined via thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The mass of 1 remains largely unchanged until the decomposition onset temperature of ∼290 °C. A 54.4% weight loss occurred by 360 °C, consistent with the loss of 1 equiv of dpa and 1 equiv of suc (55.4% predicted). All removal of organics was complete by 535 °C, indicated by a further weight loss of 32.1%, roughly consistent with expulsion of the second equivalent of dpa. The final mass remnant of 13.5% was consistent with deposition of CoO (14.4% predicted). The thermal stability of 2 was slightly greater, with an onset temperature for degradation of ∼310 °C. A precipitous weight loss of 55.7% was complete by 390 °C, corresponding to fracture of the self-interpenetrated framework with the expulsion of all suc moieties, 1 equiv of dpa, and 1 equiv of HCl (53.7% calculated). A further mass loss of 30.9% occurred between 390 and 555 °C, marking the elimination of the second equivalent of dpa. The final mass remnant of 15.4% was very close to that predicted for NiO (15.1%). 3 slowly dehydrates on heating from 25 to 225 °C (observed weight loss 2.4%, 2.5% calculated for one-half equivalent of water), followed immediately by rapid elimination of all organic moieties. The remnant at 425 °C (26.0%) is indicative of a mixture of CuCO3 and CuO. A subsequent slow decrease in mass to 800 °C likely marks further decarboxylation. The TGA trace of 4 revealed dehydration in two steps completed by 125 °C (7.0% observed, 5.0% calculated), followed by a plateau to ∼275 °C, whereupon combustion of all organic ligands commenced. The 21.9% mass remnant at 800 °C is consistent with ZnO (21.8% predicted). Compound 5 exhibited a slow mass loss of 4.5% between ∼200 °C and ∼270 °C, consistent with explusion of the cocrystallized water (4.3% predicted). Complete combustion of all organic components commenced soon thereafter, with a remnant at 450 °C roughly consistent with deposition of Cd metal (26.9% predicted, 24.0% observed). A slow mass loss above this temperature, followed by a rapid mass loss above ∼760 °C, is attributed to volatilization and vaporization of the Cd metal (bp 765 °C). TGA traces for 1−5 are given in Figures S1−S5 (Supporting Information).
